page.title: 03THE ECOLOGY OF SHALBOURNE-1
page.content: Shalbourne lies close to chalk downs with a mainly greensand subsoil with chalk and clay outcrops. It has its own microclimate, exposed to the west winds and cold air rolling off the plain, but in summer it is often drier than surrounding villages. The area is{designated for special {conservation.}A network of 49 old footpaths is recorded: only about 20 are still in regular use. The lush growth of nettles/grass requires determined voluntary effort to keep them open in summer. Though fields have been enlarged for economic farming,{bush hedgerows still survive giving cover for much wildlife. There are extensive{deciduous woodlands}at Stype and near Great Bedwyn with many fine old oak trees. There is some wet- land and an old{watercress bed}fed by two 70ft bores and by Shalbourne brook
